multicrispr 0.0.1

    • Using multicrispr

    Using multicrispr

    Aditya M Bhagwat

    using_multicrispr.Rmd

    Introduction

    The multicrispr package facilitates the design of a multi-locus crispr/cas9 library, offering a set of intuitive functions:

    • read_bed: read bedfile into GenomicRanges::GRanges object
    • flank_fourways: obtain flank ranges (if they are to be targeted)
    • find_specfic_cas9s: find offtarget-free cas9 sequences (and ranges)
    • score_cas9s: score cas9 sequences for binding efficiency.

    Read target ranges

    library(magrittr)
library(multicrispr)
bedfile      <- system.file('extdata/SRF_sites.bed', package = 'multicrispr')
bsgenome     <- BSgenome.Mmusculus.UCSC.mm10::Mmusculus
targetranges <- read_bed(bedfile, bsgenome) %>% flank_fourways()
    #   Read C:/Users/abhagwa/Documents/R/R-3.6.1/library/multicrispr/extdata/SRF_sites.bed
    #       1974 ranges on 21 chromosomes
    #       17 NT wide
    #       0 - 36535760 NT apart
    #   Flank fourways
    #       1974 left  flanks : [start-200, start-1]
    #       1974 right flanks : [end+1, end+200]
    #       3948 combined (left + right)
    #       7896 after adding strand-complements
    #       7306 after merging overlaps

    Find offtarget-free cas9s

    cas9ranges <- find_specific_cas9ranges(targetranges, mismatch = 0)
    #   Find N{20}NGG cas9seqs
    #       Rm 10 targetranges with no cas9sites
    #       9922 cas9 seqs across 33518 targetranges
    #   Find cas9seq hits
    #       with 0 mismatch(es)
    #           Count 0-mismatch hits in targetranges: 2.6 mins
    #           Count 0-mismatch hits in genome      : 2 mins
    #           Keep 6680/9922 target-specific cas9seqs
    # Returning 6680 cas9seqs across 6965 ranges

    Score cas9s

    Doench et al. (2014)’s “ruleset1” for scoring cas9 sequences is readily available:

    cas9ranges$score_rs1 <- score_cas9ranges(cas9ranges, ruleset = 1)
    #   Score contextseqs (4-23-3) with ruleset1

    The improved “ruleset2” (Doench, 2016) is also accessible, but requires for the python module azimuth to be installed and accessible as a python binary, virtual environment, or conda environment. The code chunk below shows how to score using ruleset 2 if azimuth was installed in the condaenv “default”. It also shows the common operation of filtering for rulset2 score values above 0.4.

    python_available <- assertive.reflection::is_unix() & 
                    reticulate::py_module_available('azimuth')
if (python_available){
  cas9ranges$score_rs2 <- score_cas9s(
                            cas9ranges, ruleset = 2, condaenv = 'default')
  
  message('\tFilter for scores > 0.4')
  cas9ranges %<>% extract(cas9ranges$score > 0.4)
  cmessage('\t\t%d cas9 seqs across %d ranges', 
            length(unique(cas9ranges$seqs)), 
            length(cas9ranges))
}

    References

    Doench et al. (2014). Rational design of highly active sgRNAs for CRISPR-Cas9-mediated gene inactivation. Nature Biotechnology, 32(12), doi:10.1038/nbt.3026

    Doench et al. (2016). Optimized sgRNA design to maximize activity and minimize off-target effects of CRISPR-Cas9. Nature Biotechnology, 34(7), doi:10.1038/nbt.3437
